Application_Facts: Applicant resided in Canada for 1403 days during the reference period
Residency_Compliance: Sufficient physical presence (1403 days), but lack of detailed documentation
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to clearly state the residency test applied and did not analyze relevant factors from Koo (Re)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of detailed documentation supporting residency
Credibility_Assessment: Judge approved application based on credibility
Outcome: Decision set aside, case remanded for redetermination
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Remedy_Sought: Appeal to Federal Court, reassessment by different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity on the test applied and inadequate justification

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Citizenship Judge's decision on residency requirement
Credibility_Assessment: Doubts raised due to gaps in documentation and low reported income
Evidence_Type: Lack of clear audit trails, travel records, and credible residency evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient proof of physical presence in Canada for 1095 days over four years
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant's failure to meet burden of proof for residency
Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of residency
Legal_Standard: Burden of proof on applicant to demonstrate residency

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the residence requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Appeal allowed, original decision set aside, case referred to a new citizenship judge
Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's claims were inconsistent and lacked sufficient supporting evidence
Evidence_Type: Incomplete, vague, and inconsistent documents regarding physical presence in Canada
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of residency over four years
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet Canadian citizenship residency requirements
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence of physical presence and lack of clarity in judicial reasoning
Proceeding_Type: Appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Error: Failure to specify which residency test was applied and inadequate justification
Assessment_Standard: Three judicial approaches: strict physical presence, strong attachment to Canada, or place of centralized existence
Evidence_Ignored: Inconsistencies and gaps in documentation supporting residency claims
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of the citizenship judge's decision
Application_Factor: Duration and quality of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new citizenship judge
Document_Fraud: Implied through submission of incomplete and inconsistent documents

Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in assessing residency requirements and providing adequate reasons
Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; appeal allowed and case remitted
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided inconsistent evidence regarding residency
Evidence_Type: Residency records, applicant testimony, documentation of physical presence
Legal_Provision: Residency requirement of 1,095 days within four years under Citizenship Act
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet physical presence requirement for citizenship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of clarity on which residency test was applied and inadequate analysis of contradictory evidence
Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Application_Error: Failure to specify applicable residency test and reconcile inconsistencies in evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Contradictions in the applicant's residency claims
Legal_Standard: Residency duration and quality of connection to Canada
Application_Factor: Physical presence, qualitative attachment, centralization of existence
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different citizenship judge for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge provide adequate reasons and correctly determine residency requirements under subsection 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Outcome: Appeal granted, case sent back for reassessment with clearer reasoning required
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of physical presence or constructive residence test
impact of foreign employment on residency
Application_Error: Failure to specify which residency test was applied
inadequate explanation of how evidence supports residency
Evidence_Ignored: Concerns about foreign employment not adequately addressed
Legal_Standard: Adequacy of reasons standard under administrative law

Legal_Issue: Residence requirement under the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Appeal allowed; matter referred back for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in travel records and lack of documentation not adequately addressed
Legal_Provision: Residence requirement: at least three years in Canada during the four years preceding application
Basis_of_Claim: Errors in fact and law in the citizenship judge's decision
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Application of physical presence vs. intention test
Application_Error: Failure to clearly apply appropriate test and address evidentiary gaps
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to insufficient reasoning
Document_Fraud: Potential false or incomplete documentation regarding residence

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was absent for 630 days, falling short of the 1095-day residency requirement in a four-year period
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge provided inadequate reasons; failed to specify which residency test was applied
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear explanation or documentation supporting residency compliance
Relief_Sought: Review and reversal of citizenship approval
Remedy_Sought: Remand or denial of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years
Decision_Rationale: Respondent did not meet statutory residency requirement and Citizenship Judge failed to provide adequate reasons

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer fettered discretion by failing to consider post-decision establishment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant entered with false passport and remained illegally, affecting credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations for permanent residence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary choice to remain in Canada illegally after departure order
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged failure to consider new evidence of establishment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Post-leave establishment due to applicant's deliberate non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fettering of discretion in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of time in Canada, family ties, employment
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence on H&C grounds upheld

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada using a false passport and claimed refugee status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Remained in Canada without legal status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Use of false passport constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel documents, refugee hearing record, establishment evidence

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Serious doubt due to use of fraudulent travel document

Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of law or setting aside of decision

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Post-decision establishment, due to illegality of presence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Immigration violation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Entered with false passport, refugee claim rejected, applied for H&C relief

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Consideration of new evidence after decision to leave

Application_Facts: Claimant's refugee protection claim was dismissed due to lack of psychological evidence for 'compelling reasons' under subsection 108(4)
Procedural_Issue: RAD required a psychological report not mandated by law, imposing an unreasonable burden on the claimant
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of psychological report submitted by claimant
Relief_Sought: Judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Compelling reasons under subsection 108(4) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Requirement of a psychological report is not supported by jurisprudence and fetters discretion; contradicts established case law

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days over four years, retained business interests in Colombia, and traveled frequently.
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under s. 14(5) of Citizenship Act and s. 21 of Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found stronger connection to Colombia
Relief_Sought: Grant of Canadian citizenship
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence, Koo factors
Decision_Rationale: Frequent absences and significant ties to Colombia indicated that the applicant had not centralized their life in Canada.

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the criteria for a stay of removal based on irreparable harm if returned to Sri Lanka?
Outcome: The motion for a stay of removal was dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant failed to prove irreparable harm on the balance of probabilities
Evidence_Type: Submissions, expert evidence from Mr. Schultz, PRRA Officer's findings
Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution in Sri Lanka due to high-profile Tamil gang leader status
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of specific threat or targeting of returnees like the applicant
Proceeding_Type: Federal Court review of stay of removal application
Legal_Standard: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Application_Factor: Non-speculative evidence required for irreparable harm

Risk_Assessment: No credible threat identified upon return to Sri Lanka
Risk_Type: Persecution claim based on identity and status
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony (Mr. Schultz), PRRA Officer report
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide contrary evidence

Risk_Assessment: No credible risk found upon return
Risk_Type: Persecution or harm due to profile

Legal_Issue: Qualification for stay of removal based on irreparable harm

Risk_Factor: High-profile status claimed but not verified
Evidence_Credibility: Official evidence trusted over applicant's claims

Application_Facts: Convicted in Canada, challenged PRRA outcome

Violation_Type: Refugee claim denial based on lack of objective fear and internal flight alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to political affiliation but provided insufficient evidence; Lahore was assessed as a viable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision for reasonableness
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of applicant's testimony and country condition evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to establish well-founded fear of persecution or unreasonableness of relocating to Lahore
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected by the Board
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Board's decision rejecting refugee claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must prove risk of persecution or unreasonable relocation within country
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, considering justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Decision_Rationale: Board's conclusion that applicant failed to demonstrate objective fear and that Lahore was a viable IFA was reasonable

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and lawfulness of NPB-imposed conditions
Crimes.Governing_Law: Corrections and Conditional Release Act (CCRA) s.134.1(2), Charter of Rights and Freedoms s.1
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Risk of reoffense, need for public protection, medical treatment efficacy
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant to demonstrate unreasonableness or violation of rights
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: History of sexual offenses against children
Crimes.Legal_Rule: NPB may impose reasonable and necessary conditions for public protection and reintegration under CCRA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Offender's diagnosis as pedophile, risk assessment, supervision plan
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law, criminal law, Charter rights
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Conditions violate Charter rights and exceed NPB authority
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Clinical assessment, parole board records, statutory provisions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to remove medication and no-contact conditions

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach Of Long-Term Supervision Order Conditions

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether NPB has authority to impose such conditions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Risk assessment, offender history, medical recommendations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s risk to public safety acknowledged
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Conditions upheld as lawful and reasonable
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Removal of medication and contact restrictions
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness and necessity under CCRA and s.1 justification under Charter
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conditions are necessary for public protection and justified under Charter

Crimes.Governing_Law: Corrections and Conditional Release Act, particularly provisions on long-term offenders

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of discretionary conditions attached to supervision order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: NPB’s authority to impose specific conditions on long-term offenders
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Clinical diagnosis, criminal history, risk management plan
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: High risk of reoffending acknowledged
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Removal of medication and no-contact conditions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Conditions are proportionate and necessary for public safety and reintegration

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria

Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution based on a Convention ground or personalized risk not generally faced
Decision_Rationale: Court found error in Board's determination that risk was generalized rather than personalized due to applicant's specific actions against MS 13

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate lack of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 96 or 97
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by SSP in Pakistan due to religious affiliation; alleged insufficient state protection against sectarian violence
Residency_Compliance: Claimant was in Canada and seeking refugee status; residency status pending determination
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Pakistan's efforts to control sectarian violence, including military and police presence and government initiatives
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove state inability to protect nationals in Pakistan
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant failed to demonstrate lack of state protection; credibility not explicitly challenged but burden of proof not met
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee
Stay of removal
Permanent resident status
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Convention refugee definition under IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Patently unreasonable standard applied to Board's findings
Decision_Rationale: State protection does not need to be perfect; Pakistan maintains functional military, police, and civil authority making serious efforts to protect citizens despite challenges with sectarian violence

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: The application is allowed and referred back for reconsideration by a different member
Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic abuse, lack of police protection
State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate state protection due to police failure to act
Risk_Factor: Repeated domestic abuse, risk of death
Credibility: Claim supported by repeated reports to police

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Protection by Police
Violation_Type: Failure to provide state protection in domestic violence case
Application_Facts: Applicant reported abuse five times with no police response
Procedural_Issue: Board relied on unsupported claims of improved policing
Jurisdictional_Issue: Assessment of state protection in Saint Lucia by Canadian authorities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored contrary evidence on police inaction
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant credible; education level considered
Relief_Sought: Refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proof on claimant to show lack of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board’s decision unreasonable due to flawed evidence evaluation

Victim_Status: Female survivor of long-term domestic abuse
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to history and escalation
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient: multiple police reports, detailed testimony
Credibility_Assessment: Credible despite lack of documentation

Crime_Name: Negligence in Search and Rescue Duties
Application_Facts: The ship was sold before the action commenced, disallowing in rem claims. However, the in personam claim remains valid as it falls under federal navigation and shipping jurisdiction.
Procedural_Issue: Defendants moved to strike or stay the action based on jurisdictional grounds
Jurisdictional_Issue: Can the Federal Court hear an action against federal and provincial defendants for damages arising from a boating accident under maritime law?
Decision_Outcome: The motion to strike the in personam action is dismissed; the in rem action is dismissed due to lack of continuous ownership.
Outcome: In personam action continues in Federal Court; in rem action dismissed. Defendants must file statements of defense by January 11, 2012.
Decision_Rationale: The in personam claim falls within federal navigation and shipping jurisdiction, allowing it to proceed. The in rem claim fails because the vessel was sold before the action began, breaking continuous ownership required for such claims.

Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - residency requirement (3 years in Canada within 4 years preceding application)
Application_Facts: Cynthia Wall spent most of her time abroad as a missionary; only 38 days of physical presence in Canada over four years; maintained significant ties to Canada including taxes, medical insurance, and family
Residency_Compliance: Not met based on physical presence; claim based on 'centralized mode of living' and Koo guidelines
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to fully address the legal residency requirement; improper application of Koo's guidelines; confusion between recommendations and legal analysis
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient analysis of residency criteria despite evidence of ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application initially approved by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside; case remanded for rehearing
Relief_Sought: Minister sought overturning of citizenship approval due to incorrect legal interpretation
Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before the same Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under the Citizenship Act using Koo framework (combination of physical presence and centralized mode of living)
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge did not properly apply the Koo guidelines and failed to provide adequate reasoning on whether residency requirement was met

Violation_Type: Failure to Consider Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 and Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution by FARC in Colombia; reported being tracked; sought protection due to threats; RPD found contradictions in testimony and dismissed threats for lack of evidence
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to reasonably assess credibility and did not adequately consider urban reach of FARC or Applicant's history of being tracked
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documentation supporting claims of threats and FARC targeting
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence cited by RPD for dismissing threats
Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned credibility based on inconsistencies; court found assessment unreasonable
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status based on credibility concerns and assumption of internal flight alternative in Bogota
Outcome: Judicial review granted; RPD decision overturned
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugee, protection from removal to Colombia
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred in credibility analysis and failed to consider relevant evidence regarding internal flight alternative, including FARC's presence in urban areas and Applicant's history of being targeted

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of citizenship judge's assessment of residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge accepted Pereira's explanation despite memory issues and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirement under Citizenship Act (1095 days in 4 years or strong attachment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to report six trips abroad
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of corroborating evidence and significant discrepancies in travel history
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Absence of passport records and trip documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence or strong attachment to Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Travel history and credibility of applicant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision; overturned on judicial review

Crimes.Application_Facts: Pereira failed to report six trips abroad and provided weak explanations
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of travel history affecting residency calculation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient inquiry by citizenship judge despite discrepancies
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over citizenship decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of supporting documents for travel claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Weak explanations accepted without scrutiny
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of decision and proper reassessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge failed to require credible evidence despite red flags
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Non-citizens do not have unqualified right to remain; stay requires proof of irreparable harm

Crimes.Application_Facts: U.S. citizen overstayed visitor status after prior convictions
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Non-citizen, inadmissible due to foreign convictions
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to depart by required date
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – primary issue is overstay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Seeking judicial review and stay of deportation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to prove financial or personal irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of hardship not substantiated
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and suspension of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No irreparable harm demonstrated; public interest favors enforcement

Crimes.Application_Facts: U.S. misdemeanors deemed equivalent to Canadian offenses; overstay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority to assess foreign offense equivalence
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Guilty pleas in California, dictionary definitions (Black's Law Dictionary)
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to challenge equivalence with legal authority
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s arguments on legal error not persuasive
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on legal error claim
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Equivalence of foreign offenses to Canadian crimes
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Adjudicator properly applied legal test for equivalence

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Misdemeanor classification, no indication of violence
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Moderate – misdemeanor but involving unlawful entry
Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety and integrity of immigration system
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Potential recidivism due to criminal history
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – guilty plea and statutory analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Court documents, statutory provisions (California Penal Code §459)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to rebut equivalence finding
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on foreign criminality and equivalence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Equivalence of foreign offense and deportation eligibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether U.S. theft conviction equates to Canadian offense under s. 322 of Criminal Code
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Criminal Code of Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Guilty plea in U.S., use of Black's Law Dictionary for equivalence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for stay and review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show irreparable harm and legal error
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to provide legal authority challenging equivalence method
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Foreign conviction equivalent if elements align with Canadian offense
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in using dictionary to determine legal equivalence
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed – no reversible error found
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: California Penal Code §459, Criminal Code s. 322
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation and quashing of adjudicator’s decision

Application_Facts: Applicant's age, education, ethnic origin, and baptism evidence were not considered; inappropriate questions about religious practices without specialized knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Failure to reasonably consider all evidence
Inadequate credibility assessment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to account for subjective and objective factors
Lack of comprehensive context in credibility analysis
Credibility_Assessment: Assessment found unreasonable due to lack of comprehensive analysis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Decision failed to consider all relevant factors and context; credibility assessment was inadequate

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding dates and events
Procedural_Issue: Board did not explicitly address all contrary evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in testimony despite documentary support
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant not credible due to inconsistencies; assessment deemed reasonable by court
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision on credibility grounds
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Credibility assessment in refugee claims
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was justified, transparent, intelligible, and within acceptable range of outcomes

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act s. 5, 22(1)
Application_Facts: Applicants claim RCMP improperly refuses meal allowances
Grievances are unresolved
The Commissioner's jurisdiction is not yet invoked due to incomplete grievance process
Rule 1602 does not allow class actions or general orders
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application failed to meet procedural requirements under Federal Court Rules
Grievance process was not completed before seeking judicial review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Commissioner has not yet exercised jurisdiction as grievance process remains incomplete
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review is dismissed
Outcome: Dismissed with costs awarded against respondents
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of denied meal allowances
Allegation of improper guidelines and lack of Commissioner action
Legal_Standard_Applied: Compliance with Federal Court Rules and Federal Court Act procedural requirements
Decision_Rationale: Application does not comply with procedural rules
Jurisdiction of the Commissioner has not been properly invoked
Class actions and general orders are not permitted under Rule 1602
Authority_Responsible: Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police

Application_Facts: Mr. Salim was physically present in Canada for 1099–1101 days over four years but omitted declaring six trips abroad
Residency_Compliance: Partially compliant – met physical presence threshold but with unexplained absences
Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of travel history; failure to disclose absences
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by Citizenship Judge violating procedural fairness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity on how unreported absences were assessed
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility questioned due to undeclared trips
Outcome: Case remanded to Citizenship Judge Duguay for redetermination
Relief_Sought: Overturn of citizenship approval due to inadequate reasoning
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination with clear and adequate reasons
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095-day residency requirement under Section 5(1)(c)
Adequate reasons requirement under Section 14(2)
Koo (Re) test for residency
Decision_Rationale: Although physical presence was sufficient, the judge failed to account for or explain treatment of non-declared absences, undermining transparency and fairness

Dispute_Type: Copyright ownership and standing to sue
Legal_Issue: Whether plaintiffs are entitled to costs thrown away due to late amendments by the defendant
Procedural_Stage: Post-amendment, pre-trial or trial stage regarding cost implications
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiffs failed to prove copyright creation date, standing, and title requirements
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiffs to prove standing, title, and ownership of copyright
Legal_Rule: Costs thrown away are awarded only when work becomes useless due to amendment; incidental costs follow event outcome
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged waste of costs due to defendant's late amendment on standing defense
Outcome_on_Merits: Case dismissed due to lack of evidence from plaintiffs on ownership and standing
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence (or lack thereof) regarding copyright creation date, plaintiff's title, and standing
Legal_Framework: Rules on amendment of pleadings and award of costs in civil litigation
Defendant_Response: Amended defense challenging plaintiffs' standing to sue
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence related to copyright ownership and procedural filings
Outcome: Plaintiffs not entitled to costs thrown away as amendments did not render prior work useless

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in assessing work experience and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer found discrepancies in documents and deemed them unreliable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove required caregiving experience
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Documents considered inconsistent and not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove six months of classroom training or one year of full-time live-in caregiving
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to officer's decision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged insufficient proof of experience and breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Refusal upheld due to lack of reliable evidence
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained decision based on document inconsistencies

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant failed to demonstrate required experience with authentic documents
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no costs awarded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Documents lacked consistency; signatures, formats, and prior declarations raised concerns
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient proof of work experience and questionable authenticity
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in documentation and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to submit verifiable, consistent evidence of caregiving experience
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of officer’s evaluation under IRPR
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified; officer reviewed all submitted documents
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Authentic and credible evidence required to meet IRPR standards
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspicion of fabricated or altered documents due to format and signature discrepancies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; full record considered

Crimes.Application_Factor: Failure to meet documentary burden for caregiver work permit
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Indications of potential falsification due to formatting and declaration inconsistencies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Disclose Material Facts in Immigration Context
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in visa refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Extrinsic evidence from employer (Plastik) used without notification
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant, but procedural fairness obligations on decision maker

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Visa officers must provide opportunity to respond to extrinsic evidence, consider all relevant work experience, and notify of language assessment changes
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for re-determination

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, third-party verification, application forms
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of refusal decision and re-determination
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to procedural fairness and assessment criteria

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and accuracy of information in visa assessment
Crimes.Outcome: Decision overturned and referred back for reassessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant not given chance to explain discrepancies
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on truthfulness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of unverified extrinsic evidence without notice
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of notification regarding language requirements and employment verification
Crimes.Application_Error: Overlooking relevant work experience and applying new language rules without notice
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Compliance with procedural fairness under administrative law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to inform and provide fair opportunity to respond
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience and language proficiency scoring
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged inconsistencies in employment verification, no finding of intentional fraud

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and allegations of misrepresentation

Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrect application of scoring criteria and assessment rules
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and accurate application of immigration rules
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Researcher/tutor role deemed relevant but excluded
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Duty to ensure fairness in assessment process
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience evaluation and language proficiency
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct finding of fraud; issues centered on process and communication

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to inform immigration authorities of address change

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal regarding genuineness of marriage
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in credibility findings, rendered an unreasonable decision, or violated procedural fairness

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: History of prior non-genuine marriages and inconsistencies in spousal testimony
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review for factual findings is reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior immigration applications involving marriage sponsorship

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration appeal regarding validity of marriage for sponsorship
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD erred in credibility assessment or rendered an unreasonable decision
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law on genuine marital relationships
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: IAD questioned credibility due to inconsistent testimonies and unreliable documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Marriage must be genuine and not entered into primarily for immigration benefits
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant claimed marriage was genuine and challenged IAD’s rejection
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies in wedding details, financial patterns, and living arrangements
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard in evaluating administrative decisions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review is reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Multiple prior marriages and sponsorship attempts
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision upheld; no reviewable error found

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over unpaid loans and BCR halting repayments pending litigation outcome
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the Band Council's BCR decision reviewable under judicial review and does the Applicant have standing to challenge it?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: The loans' legality was confirmed by the Saskatchewan Court of Appeal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed due to lack of standing and untimeliness
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant failed to establish direct impact or public interest standing
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Judicial review applies if applicant is directly affected or has public interest standing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to BCR halting loan repayments
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: BCR not subject to judicial review as it involves private commercial matters
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Saskatchewan Court of Appeal confirmation of loan legality
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act, internal financial management
Crimes.Defendant_Response: BCR pertains to internal financial management and does not revoke prior agreements
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, mandamus, appointment of receiver
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to Respondents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over unpaid loans and a BCR directing non-payment pending litigation outcome
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is the Band Council's BCR amenable to judicial review and does the Applicant have standing to challenge it?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to Respondents
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Court rulings, INAC communication in November 2001
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding of loan payments based on BCR during ongoing litigation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: BCR pertains to private commercial law, not federal tribunal action
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Judicial review applicable only to federal boards, commissions, or tribunals
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant not directly communicated the BCR, but informed via INAC

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer's decision violated procedural fairness or misapplied section 25 of IRPA

Evidence_Type: Evidence of integration and contributions to society

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by court
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision upheld as reasonable and transparent

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with temporary resident conditions
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25 of IRPA (application for exemption due to overstay)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered legally, overstayed visas, established life and family in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals out of status seeking permanent residence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No finding of misrepresentation; issue centered on humanitarian assessment
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons and fairness in decision-making process
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Psychological report did not support severity of claimed autism-related challenges
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of hardship not sufficiently substantiated
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for exemption denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under s. 25 IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship demonstrated; best interests of children considered but outweighed by immigration compliance
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer and Federal Court on review

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa after criminal conviction; applied for TRP due to pending permanent residency and community contributions
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – failed to leave Canada as required
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by immigration officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer considered key factors; reasons were brief but adequate given low procedural fairness threshold

Crimes.Legal_Rule: TRP may be granted under IRPA s.24 if justified by circumstances

Crimes.Legal_Framework: Discretionary assessment of need vs. risk under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Application for TRP based on rehabilitation and ties
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn TRP refusal

Legal_Issue: Was the removal of Mr. Testawich from his elected position justified under the Duncan First Nation Election Regulations?
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence supported the alleged violation of Section 4(B)
Decision_Outcome: Removal decision was unreasonable and breached procedural fairness
Burden_of_Proof: On the Committee to justify removal
Credibility_Factor: Lack of written record and clear reasons affected credibility of the Committee's decision
Legal_Rule: The Regulations and procedural fairness principles govern election disputes, with decisions reviewed for reasonableness
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged violation of election regulations by contacting electors without consent
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld in favor of Mr. Testawich
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of evidence supporting Section 4(B) violation, lack of written record
Legal_Framework: Duncan First Nation Election Regulations, principles of procedural fairness
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (lack of written record), procedural omissions
Remedy_Requested: Reinstatement, back pay, nullification of by-election, costs
Outcome: Mr. Testawich reinstated as councillor, by-election nullified, awarded back pay and costs
Authority: Election Committee, subject to judicial review

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay

Legal_Issue: Credibility of applicant's claim of political persecution
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Board doubted political activity post-1994 and political motive of 2002 incident due to omissions in police reports and immigration interviews
Legal_Provision: Definition of Convention refugee under IRPA: well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged political persecution in Sri Lanka following their party's election loss
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of the applicant's testimony and consistency of statements
Application_Error: Failure to properly assess credibility based on inconsistent reasoning
Evidence_Ignored: Potential explanations for omissions in prior statements
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard of review applied by court
Application_Factor: Timing and plausibility of political involvement after 1994
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to a different Board member for reassessment
Authority: Canadian immigration law, IRPA, Convention refugee definition
